The explosion of survival games in recent years has been fascinating to watch, because everyone has a different idea about what makes them appealing. There are some like Subnautica that go light on the survival elements to emphasize exploration and building in a vibrant world. Then there are others like The Long Dark that push you to learn and master the mechanics to survive in brutal conditions. Savage Lands appears to go in a third way, opposite the ones I just mentioned, and I'm not really sure that's the best direction to strike out in.

Savage Lands casts you as an outcast, sent to the frozen reaches of not-Skyrim presumably to die. You can customize your waxy, lumpy character with mohawks and tribal tattoos before embarking upon your exile, but harbor no illusions of making Goku or Kanye West with the handful of options present. Once you arrive in the arctic wasteland you're given a laundry list of survival tasks that act as a tutorial, directing you to chop wood, gather stones, and hunt animals. It doesn't actually tell you HOW to do these things or WHERE to find them, but I was able to puzzle them all out in fifteen minutes or so.

From there you're on your own. The landscape is helpfully dotted with ruins of shacks, cabins, and villages which you can repair with the right resources. This makes a good first goal once you find your footing, working your way up the extensive structure tree from workbenches to smelters in order to patch up your new home. In the meantime you'll have to attend to your survival, represented by two bisected gauges. The top one is health/temperature, restored with bandages and fire, and the bottom is stamina/hunger, restored by eating and not running around all willy-nilly. It's arranged in this way so that hunger and temperature can eat into your other resources if left unchecked, which becomes a major consideration in blizzards or on long treks.

As you scavenge across the land you'll find notes scattered about that give bits of lore or hints at how features like armor work. You'll also find quite a few points of interest like ruined forts and towers that usually contain some loose tools to appropriate. The other thing you'll find are monsters, and in no short supply. Your starting area is mostly populated with rabbits, deer, and the occasional brittle skeleton that needs to be smashed. Travel more than a hundred meters in any direction, though, and you'll have wolves tearing your throat out. Preparation is a must for longer journeys, as just one tough foe getting the drop on you can spell disaster. They won't give up once they spot you, either, a fact I was distressed to learn after leading a wolf back to my camp.

There's plenty more to be distressed about, too. Creatures in the world have some of the worst collision and hit detection I've ever seen, vibrating through rocks and walls and hitting you from a yard away. If you're not beating on monsters you'll probably be beating on mineral deposits, because mining is key to progression and takes a ridiculously long time to dig out anything more valuable than coal. Other resources like clay are bound to be a complete mystery unless you try literally everything or consult a wiki. And in a perfect example of how little quality-of-life there is here, a basic container to place in the world takes fairly advanced materials to make, meaning all your junk is going to be sitting in a pile in the snow for a few hours until you can finally craft a fucking wooden chest.

I would be more willing to stick out the rough gameplay if the game had some other appeal, but it really, really does not. You may have noticed that the screenshots on the store page have a lot of similar daytime scenes. That's because this is probably the grayest game I've ever played, and that's counting stuff like LIMBO. The world is almost completely devoid of color; the snowfields are gray, the foliage is brownish-gray, the stonework is blueish-gray, even the monsters are all grays and browns. There's not much detail to the models either, and the animations tend to be slower and stiffer than you'd expect.

There's certainly potential in Savage Lands, but it won't be realized without some major overhauls that probably aren't within the scope of the project. The visuals are a dreary mess and the progression is needlessly tedious and complicated. And even if you come to grips with that, you're likely to be eaten by a wolf or a dragon and spat out to the main menu. I get the appeal of open-world survival Skyrim but this is missing so many simple balance and accessibility elements that I don't know how you get there from here. If this game ever shapes up I'll revisit the frozen hells therein, but until then I have little interest in sticking it out.

Put another way, some people have found it worthwhile to devise farming runs for the nodes to reduce time spent gathering minerals.  It just doesn't feel right here.

The crafting menu is still very annoying to use, especially when you aren't completely sure what something in the miscellaneous section is named (great example is when you go looking for nails because you see they are needed to repair a building, but they are actually named "Bag of Nails" in the rather long, alphabetized list). Buildings/crafting stations are still all together in a 4-per-page list that would really be better served by a section in the crafting menu, though perhaps there is an issue with the coding (since they go to outline-placement mode instead of producing an item) preventing this.

Some bugs/design issues:  It looks like they're in the middle of some terrain changes on the islands.  Especially on the second island, there are a lot of rocks and other objects floating a few feet off the ground in many places.

With regards to the warmth mechanics, it still feels odd to me that it not only reduces your max health but also your actual health.  I get that it's supposed to be another layer of the survival gameplay, but it's really annoying to need to bandage myself just because I went outside for a few minutes before coming back to warm up.

Combat is... dull, I suppose is the correct work.  Yeah, your life is on the line with vicious monsters, but you just trudge around swinging mechanically.  There's no real intensity to it. Overall, it seems like there is a desire to avoid out-of-character tutorial information, but I'm not sure whether that is appropriate to a game demanding you make survival choices.  If the character has the know-how to make a leanto, it seems reasonable to inform players of how to do so within the system.  Likewise with the fact that some mineral resources are found in discrete nodes while others are randomly generated by bashing any rock.  If they want to keep it completely in-world, a few more books in the starter area mentioning the basics would be great for new players.

There needs to be a decision on which direction to focus on for the moment:  Either improve the crafting side of things with better interface and more options (particularly with regards to structures) or emphasize the exploration and combat side with improved enemies (at the moment they seem mechanical, have 1 or 2 attacks that frequently have janky hit ranges, and depend mostly on huge health pools and damage compared to the player).  Right now it feels like the game is trying to do too many things at once, but I think some focused attention in each area one at a time will really help.  My personal preference would be the combat system since the game doesn't really fit the builder/crafter mold.

Despite many flaws, I really like the game. The graphics are rather dated, but these aren't "bad" by any means. Makes one think of some oldschool games. The exploration it offers is really decent. A large map with each location different from another. Even though there hardly are any POI's with loot, it's still interesting to explore them. Co-op experience is great and I had fun with my friend... while it lasted.



Why not recommended then? The current state of the game is hardly playable sadly. As much as I like the game, it constantly tests your patience with its clunky design, and crashes from time to time on top of that. Let me mention things I didn't like:



[h1]Tons of bugs and random crashing[/h1]

I had a run with almost 30 hours in it and the game suddenly crashed without any information whatsoever, it just kicked me out to Desktop. It happened two times during this playthrough. The second time... when I loaded the game back, my entire inventory was wiped out. The problem is, that I carried absolutely everything with me, didn't have anything stored in chests, so that means, that the game literally destroyed 30 hours of my progress with a single crash. There's no character level, nor anything like this that would stay, so all the "progress" was gone. I'd have to start everything from scratch. This is beyond unacceptable, it was a definite "enough" for me. I abandoned this ship.



[h1]Terrible Interface & Inventory Management[/h1]

It's been years and the interface is still insanely obnoxious. Inventory management is such a pain. There's no way to quickly store items in the chest, no shift-clicking nor anything, every single item has to be dragged manually. Stacking items in chests often leads to them being dropped instead. Even just scrolling through the inventory is poorly programmed. Mouse wheel stops scrolling when the cursor is on any of the inventory slots, works when it's precisely put on the grid in-between the slots. Swapping two items is also tragic. Even in toolbelt (that has not enough slots by the way), when trying to swap two items, the other one ends up being moved to first free slot in inventory. Nothing works properly and I have no idea how that system managed to survive through these years.



[h1]Slow, Clunky And Unbalanced Combat[/h1]

The combat is wonky in general. Enemies hit hard and you can't dodge majority of attacks, due to unfair hitboxes of their attacks. There are 2H weapons with longer reach, but even these are nothing compared to some enemies' reach range, as they can hit you from far away. Some enemies also have AoE attacks while they shouldn't. A skeleton with bare hands punching towards one direction may still score a hit on you when you're standing BEHIND him, literally. So many times you'll be asking "How did he hit me?" in this game, because I and my friend were constantly asking that question. Some enemies work normally, can be dodged when knowing how and when, and are balanced well, especially those on the first island. But after that, it's just circus, you are supposed to get hit and deal with it. Majority of combat afterwards relies mostly on holding left mouse button and seeing who dies first, while drinking some potions once in a while. One could use a shield to try to achieve something, but you'll have to repair it too often. Those enemies don't really drop anything useful, and fixing your equipment will cost you ores you used to craft them (for Silver tier and above), which makes it absolutely not worth fighting anyone in late game. The time (and suffering) required to mine these ores is much greater than the time you'll be fighting in equipment made with it, especially for Gold tier, as gold ores spawn ONLY in few, poorly chosen locations. These ores are hidden in mountains without clear paths, so you'll end up having to suffer from terrible jumping mechanics to get to them... and cycle around these few spots or maybe just afk and wait for them to respawn.



Yes, enemies do drop best equipment in game, but it's pretty much only true for end-game bosses, otherwise it's best to skip combat and focus on mining ores and fight only the bosses required to progress further. I've been to dungeons, where everyone were hitting hard, especially mini-bosses that steal like 50% of HP per hit in the best-to-that-point armor. I manage to kill them by abusing their galaxy intelligence and what do I get? Some random weapon that maybe is better than the current one I have, but is worse than the weapon I'd craft with the ores of 1-higher tier, so conclusion is simple - instead of wasting resources and struggling with clunky combat, just sneak around mountains and mine ores - not only you'll be able to craft a better weapon, you'll also craft a better armor while you're at it. The only time I was actually happy with enemy loot was when I killed the mini-boss in the very-first dungeon (Meltok) and got the green skull for off-hand slot that increased movement speed and stamina recovery - and it also didn't require any mindblowing materials to repair, as it didn't require fixing at all, so I was truly able to enjoy the loot. Another loot from boss I enjoyed was that ice sword that generated heat when held, which was great too, especially because items rarely have such special effects. There is some good loot that is true, but out of so many enemies and 30h of gameplay, only these two items were worthwile.



There definitely could be some more loot, that preferably would not require materials, that can be found in one specific spot only to fix.



[h1]Rather Boring Resource Gathering[/h1]

At first it's not bad to be honest. You can easily find various ores as you go and cutting trees is satisfying enough... Maybe except some bushes that have odd hitbox and are hard to hit.

Generally at the beginning it all appears to be pretty promising, but some time later you will get tired of that. Ores "grow" only in specific spots, so there are no surprises. The same ore will regrow in the same spot endlessly. First tiers are all over the place, so you can gather them while exploring, but later, it requires you to go to specific locations. It gets worse with each ore tier, because they get rarer. As I mentioned earlier, there are only few spots with gold ore, and they are shamelessly placed in hardly reachable places, effectively making it a pain. Seeing how fast the durability of your equipment depletes is really discouraging, because that means more wonky jumping around mountains. It will take bunch of ingots to repair the armor, and all the loot you get from enemies is maybe few ores if you're lucky enough. Not stonks. If there was a level system or something, that alone would make it more worthwhile, but there's nothing like this, so you can literally lose resources and have absolutely nothing from it.

If the game is designed to mine often, they should make it more satisfying, rather than being forced to backtrack to very specific spots. Some caves with random ores could be a good start. That, or make all equipment repairable with common materials, like early weapons require whetstones, that aren't hard to make.



[h1]=== Conclusion ===[/h1]

These are my main issues with the game. I often felt like the invested time wasn't worth that. It's more punishing than rewarding. I went through combat mostly by abusing enemies' AI, as they can be easily cheesed with structures, but that just isn't how it should be.

I really like the game (it surely has potential) and I'm looking forward to future updates, but there are still things that need to be addressed first before I'll be able to recommend it to others. Patience is required to play this game, and a friend to play with. I absolutely don't recommend tackling it solo. With friends you can at least laugh at poor mechanics, playing solo will only make you suffer, as the game is very slow-paced.

[h1]A game I struggled with, learned, and now love.[/h1]

I was quickly able to send my new character into the old game and 'rescue' my old body - hurrah! - and take advantage of all of the bits and bobs I'd collected in that game. I can help my out my friends in online games, and that help can be carried back to their own solo games if desired. I love the idea of being able to help people out by just giving them a little bit of a leg up - not dumping gamebreaking gear on them the instant they arrive on the first island, but just the odd thing here and there to make it all a bit easier. Perhaps stand there and take the damage from Lord Kruul while they whack him with whatever they have, moving away from time to time so that they can get an idea of the damage he does to them and whether they want to retreat and improve their gear or not. 

[h1]The realisation that both the characters and the world are completely fluid has completely changed my view of the game.[/h1] 
Before, it was [i]that slightly scary game[/i] which was very much all or nothing, feeling like a proper permadeath unless you happen to leave stashes of gear tucked away for emergencies.
